Lines.Text: examine the garment where your ribbon button came off . there should be a little pocket where the ribbon came out .
stitch rip the seam around the little pocket until it is large enough to easily slide the ribbon in .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the garment where your ribbon button came off. There should be a little pocket where the ribbon came out. Stitch rip the seam around the little pocket until it is large enough to easily slide the ribbon in.

Lines.Text: tuck one end of the ribbon into the pocket , inserting the ribbon past the missing seam .
if you are are using a ribbon that has an obvious front and back , insert the ribbon so that the back is facing out .

Steps.Text_raw: Tuck one end of the ribbon into the pocket, inserting the ribbon past the missing seam. If you are are using a ribbon that has an obvious front and back, insert the ribbon so that the back is facing out.

Lines.Text: holding the ribbon in place , slide the garment into the sewing machine , aligning the sewing glossarysection_presser_footpresser foot with the place you want the button to sit .
do not sew the pocket with the ribbon end in it closed .
sew the ribbon in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Holding the ribbon in place, slide the garment into the sewing machine, aligning the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Presser_Foot|presser foot]] with the place you want the button to sit. Do not sew the pocket with the ribbon end in it closed. Sew the ribbon in place.

Lines.Text: sewing glossarysection_backstitchbackstitch to hold the stitches in place .
lift the presser foot and remove the garment from the sewing machine .
clip any threads .

Steps.Text_raw: [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Backstitch|Backstitch]] to hold the stitches in place. Lift the presser foot and remove the garment from the sewing machine. Clip any threads.

Lines.Text: thread the ribbon through the button coming up from behind , over the spoke in the middle , and back down through the second hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Thread the ribbon through the button coming up from behind, over the spoke in the middle, and back down through the second hole.

Lines.Text: pull the ribbon taught .
the button should be facing with the backside out .
fold the button and ribbon back over , so that the other side of the button is facing out .
leave just enough ribbon to tuck into the little pocket . clip all excess ribbon .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the ribbon taught. The button should be facing with the backside out. Fold the button and ribbon back over, so that the other side of the button is facing out. Leave just enough ribbon to tuck into the little pocket. Clip all excess ribbon.

Lines.Text: fold the free end of the ribbon , tucking it into the little pocket , in the same manner as the first .
overlap the two ends of the ribbon so that they sit directly on top of one another .
sew directly over the seam , closing the little pocket .
this seam should catch both ends of the ribbon between the two layers of the pocket .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the free end of the ribbon, tucking it into the little pocket, in the same manner as the first. Overlap the two ends of the ribbon so that they sit directly on top of one another. Sew directly over the seam, closing the little pocket. This seam should catch both ends of the ribbon between the two layers of the pocket.

Lines.Text: backstitch to hold the seam in place .
remove the garment from the sewing machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Backstitch to hold the seam in place. Remove the garment from the sewing machine.

Lines.Text: clip any threads .
admire your handiwork .

Steps.Text_raw: Clip any threads. Admire your handiwork.

Title: How to remove scratches from a Breitling Navitimer sapphire watch face

Lines.Text: '''notice the horrible scratch on my breitling navitimer around the 12 hand , it's actually a borderline crack . '''
you will need all of the following : diamond paste - 3 different grades
a hand held dremel tool using felt tip . you can try to use a papertowel and buff the face but it doesn't knock out the job like a dremel . i bought mine at walmart for 25 dollars .

Steps.Text_raw: '''NOTICE THE HORRIBLE SCRATCH ON MY BREITLING NAVITIMER AROUND THE 12 HAND, it's actually a borderline crack. ''' You WILL NEED all of the following: diamond paste - 3 different grades A hand held Dremel tool using felt tip. You can try to use a papertowel and buff the face but it doesn't knock out the job like a Dremel. I bought mine at Walmart for $25 dollars.

Lines.Text: first , remove your watch band from your watch .
after you have removed your watch band from the watch case . next step is to remove the bezel from the casing .
take butter knife from your kitchen and slide it between the watch case and bezel and pry it up as you twist . you will feel a pop and the bezel will be freed from the watch case .
place your watch dial in the watch case under a cup or dust protector to avoid getting dust and lint on your watch .

Steps.Text_raw: First, remove your watch band from your watch. After you have removed your watch band from the watch case. Next step is to remove the bezel from the casing. Take butter knife from your kitchen and slide it between the watch case and bezel and pry it up as you twist. You will feel a pop and the bezel will be freed from the watch case. Place your watch dial in the watch case under a cup or dust protector to avoid getting dust and lint on your watch.

Lines.Text: rather than removing the glass from the bezel , i just left it in . it is advisable to always remove the glass completely , but i did not as the materials being used will not harm the bezel . exercise caution and do not rush yourself .
you will have three different grade diamond pastes . i use a 6 , 3 , 1. . . it's always better to do a 6 , 3 , . 25
the lowest grade diamond paste is good for refinishing with a glossy mirror finish .

Steps.Text_raw: Rather than removing the glass from the bezel, I just left it in. It is advisable to always remove the glass completely, but I did not as the materials being used will not harm the bezel. Exercise caution and do not rush yourself. You will have three different grade diamond pastes.  I use a 6, 3, 1... It's always better to do a 6, 3, .25 The lowest grade diamond paste is good for refinishing with a glossy mirror finish.

Lines.Text: start with level 6 diamond paste
you will apply about a dime size of paste , then using your finger to spread the paste evenly around the watch face .
after spreading out the diamond paste , turn your dremel on its lowest speed and apply the felt tip to the watch face .
important : rotate the dremel in circular motions as you work around the sapphire . do not press to hard or dremel too long on a specific area , it could crack your face .
take little 20 second breaks allowing the face to cool down , if it over heats it could be many problems .
you will repeat the same steps above for each grade of diamond paste .
apply a little more pressure on the really scratched area to get better results .

note when you press harder on specific areas using your dremel make sure your not overheating the crystal , it can heat up in a matter of 5 seconds . touch the area scratched often to ensure its cool .

Steps.Text_raw: Start with level 6 diamond paste You will apply about a dime size of paste, then using your finger to spread the paste evenly around the watch face. After spreading out the diamond paste, turn your Dremel on its lowest speed and apply the felt tip to the watch face. IMPORTANT: rotate the Dremel in circular motions as you work around the sapphire. DO NOT press to hard or Dremel too long on a specific area, it could crack your face. Take little 20 second breaks allowing the face to cool down, if it over heats it could be many problems. You will repeat the same steps above for each grade of diamond paste. Apply a little more pressure on the really scratched area to get better results. NOTE* when you press harder on specific areas using your Dremel make sure your not overheating the crystal, it can heat up in a matter of 5 seconds. Touch the area scratched often to ensure its cool.

Lines.Text: after removing the scratches from your watch face , then snap your bezel back on and re-attach your links .
lastly , i used some car wax on my watch face to give it that gleem .
i highly highly recommend getting some cape cod cloths . they are amazing . wipe down your wrist band with this and it will remove scratches and polish your watch .
the result perfection !
hope you enjoyed this tutorial . notice the scratch on my breitling is completely gone !

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the scratches from your watch face, then snap your bezel back on and re-attach your links. Lastly, I used some car wax on my watch face to give it that gleem. I HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend getting some cape cod cloths. They are AMAZING. Wipe down your wrist band with this and it will remove scratches and polish your watch. The RESULT = PERFECTION! Hope you enjoyed this tutorial. Notice the scratch on my Breitling is completely gone!

Lines.Text: examine the damage . clip any long , loose threads , and remove any debris from the hole .
measure the length and width of the hole .
in our case it looks like 2 by 1.

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damage. Clip any long, loose threads, and remove any debris from the hole. Measure the length and width of the hole. In our case it looks like 2" by 1".

Lines.Text: grab a scrap of denim or other heavy-weight fabric and mark your measurements plus one inch in each direction .
in our case it will be 3 by 2.
cut the scrap into a rectangle the dimensions of your new measurements .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab a scrap of denim or other heavy-weight fabric and mark your measurements plus one inch in each direction. In our case it will be 3" by 2". Cut the scrap into a rectangle the dimensions of your new measurements.

Lines.Text: insert the rectangle of fabric into the jean leg and position it under the hole .
be sure that you put the rectangle of fabric in the pant leg and not behind ityou only want to work on one layer of fabric .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the rectangle of fabric into the jean leg and position it under the hole. Be sure that you put the rectangle of fabric in the pant leg and not behind it—you only want to work on one layer of fabric.

Lines.Text: thread your sewing machine with your desired thread color .
slide the pant leg onto the arm of the sewing machine .
you may need to remove the sewing machine table for the pant leg to fit over the arm .
be sure that the pant leg is around the arm of the sewing machine . if both layers are stacked on one another , you will sew the pant leg shut .

Steps.Text_raw: Thread your sewing machine with your desired thread color. Slide the pant leg onto the arm of the sewing machine. You may need to remove the sewing machine table for the pant leg to fit over the arm. Be sure that the pant leg is around the arm of the sewing machine. If both layers are stacked on one another, you will sew the pant leg shut.

Lines.Text: check that the rectangle of fabric is still laying flat , centered beneath the hole .
lower the pressor foot .
sew a straight line over the hole going about five stitches past the damage .

Steps.Text_raw: Check that the rectangle of fabric is still laying flat, centered beneath the hole. Lower the pressor foot. Sew a straight line over the hole going about five stitches past the damage.

Lines.Text: lift the pressor foot .
rotate the jean leg a few degrees toward the center of the hole .
lower the pressor foot .
engage the backstitch function on your sewing machine , and sew a straight line back over the hole , going about five stitches beyond the damage .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the pressor foot. Rotate the jean leg a few degrees toward the center of the hole. Lower the pressor foot. Engage the backstitch function on your sewing machine, and sew a straight line back over the hole, going about five stitches beyond the damage.

Lines.Text: repeat steps five and six , continuing to rotate and sew lines of stitching back and forth until you cover the entire hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat steps five and six, continuing to rotate and sew lines of stitching back and forth until you cover the entire hole.

Lines.Text: when you are satisfied with your stitching , backstitch two or three stitches .
lift the needle and pressor foot .
slide the jean leg off of the sewing machine .

Steps.Text_raw: When you are satisfied with your stitching, backstitch two or three stitches. Lift the needle and pressor foot. Slide the jean leg off of the sewing machine.

Lines.Text: clip any dangling threads and admire your work .

Steps.Text_raw: Clip any dangling threads and admire your work.

Lines.Text: still not satisfied ? alrighty , let's add some decorative stitching the other way .
this is completely optional . if you are happy with your work , you can stop here .
slide the pant leg back onto the arm of the sewing machine , making sure that the leg goes around the arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Still not satisfied? Alrighty, let's add some decorative stitching the other way. This is completely optional. If you are happy with your work, you can stop here. Slide the pant leg back onto the arm of the sewing machine, making sure that the leg goes around the arm.

Lines.Text: carefully rotate the jean leg 90 degrees .
be sure that there is only one layer of fabric ( plus the rectangle ) between the sewing machine and the needle , or else you will sew the pant leg shut .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully rotate the jean leg 90 degrees. Be sure that there is only one layer of fabric (plus the rectangle) between the sewing machine and the needle, or else you will sew the pant leg shut.

Lines.Text: lower the pressor foot .
sew a straight line of stitching over the damaged area .

Steps.Text_raw: Lower the pressor foot. Sew a straight line of stitching over the damaged area.

Lines.Text: just like before , at the end of each line of stitching , lift the pressor foot , rotate the jeans a few degrees , and sew another line of stitching .
when you are happy with the way that the stitching looks , backstitch two or three stitches .

Steps.Text_raw: Just like before, at the end of each line of stitching, lift the pressor foot, rotate the jeans a few degrees, and sew another line of stitching. When you are happy with the way that the stitching looks, backstitch two or three stitches.

Lines.Text: lift the pressor foot and needle .
slide the pant leg off the arm of the sewing machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the pressor foot and needle. Slide the pant leg off the arm of the sewing machine.

Lines.Text: clip any dangling threads .

Steps.Text_raw: Clip any dangling threads.

Lines.Text: examine the damage . clip any long threads , and remove any debris from the hole .
measure the damaged area .
in our case it looks to be 2 by 2.

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damage. Clip any long threads, and remove any debris from the hole. Measure the damaged area. In our case it looks to be 2" by 2".

Lines.Text: draw any the shape you'd like your patch to be on a piece of paper . be sure your design is at least 1 /8 larger than the damaged area .
cut out your design .

Steps.Text_raw: Draw any the shape you'd like your patch to be on a piece of paper. Be sure your design is at least 1/8" larger than the damaged area. Cut out your design.

Lines.Text: lay the cutout of your design over the hole in the jeans to make sure that it is the correct size and looks how you want it to .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the cutout of your design over the hole in the jeans to make sure that it is the correct size and looks how you want it to.

Lines.Text: using a pencil , pen , or tailor's chalk , trace the design onto the jeans .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a pencil, pen, or tailor's chalk, trace the design onto the jeans.

Lines.Text: cut the design out of your jeans .
be sure to only cut one layer of denim , or you will cut through the back of your jeans and need two patches !

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the design out of your jeans. Be sure to only cut one layer of denim, or you will cut through the back of your jeans and need two patches!

Lines.Text: take the scrap of fabric you will use for a patch and insert it into the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the scrap of fabric you will use for a patch and insert it into the hole.

Lines.Text: slide the pant leg with the patch over the arm of the sewing machine .
you may need to remove the sewing machine table for the pant to fit over the sewing machine .
if you are still having trouble getting the pant around the arm of the sewing machine , you can rip the side seam of the pant leg to allow room to sew .
be sure that the pant leg is around the arm , and that you are not accidentally sewing the two layers of the pant leg together .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the pant leg with the patch over the arm of the sewing machine. You may need to remove the sewing machine table for the pant to fit over the sewing machine. If you are still having trouble getting the pant around the arm of the sewing machine, you can rip the side seam of the pant leg to allow room to sew. Be sure that the pant leg is around the arm, and that you are not accidentally sewing the two layers of the pant leg together.

Lines.Text: adjust the sewing machine for a zig-zag stitch .
set the stitch length to just under 1 /2.

Steps.Text_raw: Adjust the sewing machine for a zig-zag stitch. Set the stitch length to just under 1/2.

Lines.Text: align the edge of the patch with the center of the pressor foot .
be sure that the patch is laying flat .
lower the pressor foot .
begin sewing the zig-zag stitch , following the edge of the hole so that the zig-zag stitch covers the area where the two fabrics meet .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the edge of the patch with the center of the pressor foot. Be sure that the patch is laying flat. Lower the pressor foot. Begin sewing the zig-zag stitch, following the edge of the hole so that the zig-zag stitch covers the area where the two fabrics meet.

Lines.Text: sew all the way around the patch .
overlap the stitching at the end with the first two or three stitches .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew all the way around the patch. Overlap the stitching at the end with the first two or three stitches.

Lines.Text: lift the pressor foot and needle .
slide the pant leg off of the arm of the sewing machine .
clip any threads , and admire your work .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the pressor foot and needle. Slide the pant leg off of the arm of the sewing machine. Clip any threads, and admire your work.

Lines.Text: examine the damage . clip any loose threads and remove any debris from the tear .
grab a trendy patch .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damage. Clip any loose threads and remove any debris from the tear. Grab a trendy patch.

Lines.Text: position the patch over the hole .
any patch you use should overlap the damage by at least 1 /8.

Steps.Text_raw: Position the patch over the hole. Any patch you use should overlap the damage by at least 1/8".

Lines.Text: pin the patch to the jeans .
be sure to only pin the patch to one layer of denim , or you will sew the pants shut .

Steps.Text_raw: Pin the patch to the jeans. Be sure to only pin the patch to one layer of denim, or you will sew the pants shut.

Lines.Text: slide the jeans into the sewing machine , positioning the needle over the edge of the patch .
be sure you only have one layer of the jeans between the needle and the sewing machine arm , or you will sew the pants shut .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the jeans into the sewing machine, positioning the needle over the edge of the patch. Be sure you only have one layer of the jeans between the needle and the sewing machine arm, or you will sew the pants shut.

Lines.Text: lower the pressor foot .
sew along the edge of the patch .
remove the pins before you get to them .
sewing over a pin can bend or break the needle .

Steps.Text_raw: Lower the pressor foot. Sew along the edge of the patch. Remove the pins before you get to them. Sewing over a pin can bend or break the needle.

Lines.Text: continue sewing around the patch , lifting the pressor foot to turn at corners of the patch .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue sewing around the patch, lifting the pressor foot to turn at corners of the patch.

Lines.Text: when you come all the way around , overlap the first two or three stitches .
lift the needle and pressor foot .
slide the jeans out of the sewing machine .
clip any threads , and admire your work .

Steps.Text_raw: When you come all the way around, overlap the first two or three stitches. Lift the needle and pressor foot. Slide the jeans out of the sewing machine. Clip any threads, and admire your work.

Lines.Text: these are the tools i used to insert the screw through the spring hinge . in the video a paperclip was used , but the paperclip i had on-hand could not fit into the tiny recess in order to jam the spring open .

Steps.Text_raw: These are the tools I used to insert the screw through the spring hinge. In the video a paperclip was used, but the paperclip I had on-hand could not fit into the tiny recess in order to jam the spring open.

Lines.Text: the problem at hand : the screw will not fit through the arm because a spring is pulling on the hinge ( and screw hole ) in the arm .

Steps.Text_raw: The problem at hand: The screw will not fit through the arm because a spring is pulling on the hinge (and screw hole) in the arm.

Lines.Text: insert a pushpin through the hole and use it as leverage to extend the spring hinge outwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a pushpin through the hole and use it as leverage to extend the spring hinge outwards.

Lines.Text: be careful not to push the pushpin into your finger , as opposed to the small notch that you've just uncovered .
once the spring hinge extends outward with the first pushpin , use a second pushpin to keep the hole in the extended position :
there will be a small notch revealed once the spring hinge extends outwards . wedge the second pushpin into that notch so that the hinge doesn't go back inwards .
i sadly only have two hands , so i was not able to show how to wedge the pushpin ''and'' take the photo .

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful not to push the pushpin into your finger, as opposed to the small notch that you've just uncovered. Once the spring hinge extends outward with the first pushpin, use a second pushpin to keep the hole in the "extended" position: There will be a small notch revealed once the spring hinge extends outwards. Wedge the second pushpin into that notch so that the hinge doesn't go back inwards. I sadly only have two hands, so I was not able to show how to wedge the pushpin ''and'' take the photo.

Lines.Text: with the second pushpin hanging around , line up the eyeglass frame/arm holes together .
use a pair of tweezers to insert your eyeglass screw through both holes .

Steps.Text_raw: With the second pushpin hanging around, line up the eyeglass frame/arm holes together. Use a pair of tweezers to insert your eyeglass screw through both holes.

Lines.Text: finally , use a 1.2 mm flat-blade screwdriver to secure the arm to the frame .
presto-blamo ! your eyeglasses are fixed .
the same procedure can be used on sunglasses without any problems .

Steps.Text_raw: Finally, use a 1.2 mm flat-blade screwdriver to secure the arm to the frame. Presto-blamo! Your eyeglasses are fixed. The same procedure can be used on sunglasses without any problems.

Lines.Text: begin by assessing the pants' current length . this is best done by wearing the pants along with an appropriate pair of shoes .
wearing pants barefoot or with high heels will affect their length relative to the floor .
it's helpful to have a second person assist with this step and the two that follow .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by assessing the pants' current length. This is best done by wearing the pants along with an appropriate pair of shoes. Wearing pants barefoot or with high heels will affect their length relative to the floor. It's helpful to have a second person assist with this step and the two that follow.

Lines.Text: fold the cuff of one pant leg inward , and adjust it to the desired length .
insert two or three pins to hold the cuff in position .
the pins should be placed parallel to the new fold .
with the pins in place , verify that the length is correct .
make any final adjustments to the length as needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the cuff of one pant leg inward, and adjust it to the desired length. Insert two or three pins to hold the cuff in position. The pins should be placed parallel to the new fold. With the pins in place, verify that the length is correct. Make any final adjustments to the length as needed.

Lines.Text: on a flat , clean surface , lay the pants down on their side with the newly shortened pant leg on top .
using a ruler , note the distance from the edge of the old cuff to the edge of the new cuff .
repeat the measurement several times along the width of the cuff , making sure the new hemline is perfectly even .

Steps.Text_raw: On a flat, clean surface, lay the pants down on their side with the newly shortened pant leg on top. Using a ruler, note the distance from the  edge of the old cuff to the edge of the new cuff. Repeat the measurement several times along the width of the cuff, making sure the new hemline is perfectly even.

Lines.Text: thread the sewing machine , using a thread color that matches your garment's fabric as closely as possible .
sewing machine setup varies from one model to another . consult your sewing machine manual for precise instructions .
place the first cuff on the sewing machine , and position the sewing needle between one of your pins and the edge of the cuff .

Steps.Text_raw: Thread the sewing machine, using a thread color that matches your garment's fabric as closely as possible. Sewing machine setup varies from one model to another. Consult your sewing machine manual for precise instructions. Place the first cuff on the sewing machine, and position the sewing needle between one of your pins and the edge of the cuff.

Lines.Text: gently depress the foot pedal and begin sewing .

be sure the needle penetrates the pant leg on only one side . it may be easier to position the pant leg around the arm of the sewing machine with the table removed . if you sew through both layers , you will sew the pant leg shut !
pause when you reach a pin , and remove it before continuing .
do not attempt to sew over any pins . hitting a pin can bend or break the sewing machine needle .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently depress the foot pedal and begin sewing. Be sure the needle penetrates the pant leg on only one side. It may be easier to position the pant leg around the arm of the sewing machine with the table removed. If you sew through both layers, you will sew the pant leg shut! Pause when you reach a pin, and remove it before continuing. Do not attempt to sew over any pins. Hitting a pin can bend or break the sewing machine needle.

Lines.Text: continue sewing all the way around the cuff , until you reach the first few stitches .
sew over the first few stitches to prevent the stitches from unraveling .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue sewing all the way around the cuff, until you reach the first few stitches. Sew over the first few stitches to prevent the stitches from unraveling.

Lines.Text: raise the presser foot , and remove the pants from the sewing machine .
clip any threads .

Steps.Text_raw: Raise the presser foot, and remove the pants from the sewing machine. Clip any threads.

Lines.Text: turn the cuff over so that the extra length of the hem folds out .
clip the extra length , leaving about a half inch of fabric beyond the seam .
be sure to only cut through one layer of the fabricthe excess fabric . do not cut through the pants .
this step is optional . if you are hemming pants for a growing kiddo , leaving the excess length allows you to rip the seam and magically lengthen the pants later on .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the cuff over so that the extra length of the hem folds out. Clip the extra length, leaving about a half inch of fabric beyond the seam. Be sure to only cut through one layer of the fabric—the excess fabric. Do not cut through the pants. This step is optional. If you are hemming pants for a growing kiddo, leaving the excess length allows you to rip the seam and magically lengthen the pants later on.

Lines.Text: set your sewing machine to a zigzag stitch .
insert the freshly cut edge of the hem into the sewing machine .
be sure to only insert one layer of fabricthe hemor you will sew through the outer , visible layers of the pants .

Steps.Text_raw: Set your sewing machine to a zigzag stitch. Insert the freshly cut edge of the hem into the sewing machine. Be sure to only insert one layer of fabric—the hem—or you will sew through the outer, visible layers of the pants.

Lines.Text: sew around the hem , as close to the edge as possible .
zigzagging the edge prevents the edge from unraveling .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew around the hem, as close to the edge as possible. Zigzagging the edge prevents the edge from unraveling.

Lines.Text: lift the presser foot and remove the pants from the sewing machine .
clip any excess threads .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the presser foot and remove the pants from the sewing machine. Clip any excess threads.

Title: How To Repair A Baffle On A Patagonia Down Jacket

Lines.Text: locate the hole in your down jacket . in order to prevent all the feathers from escaping through the hole , you'll have to replace the entire baffle .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the hole in your down jacket. In order to prevent all the feathers from escaping through the hole, you'll have to replace the entire baffle.

Lines.Text: cut a small oval of tenacious tape large enough cover the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut a small oval of Tenacious Tape large enough cover the hole.

Lines.Text: peel the backing off the tape , and apply it to the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel the backing off the tape, and apply it to the hole.

Lines.Text: use a seam ripper to rip the sewing glossarysection_seamseam at the end of baffle that needs a repair . in this case , the nearest seam is along the sleeve .
rip a large segment of the seam , so that the jacket is comfortable to work with .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a seam ripper to rip the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Seam|seam]] at the end of baffle that needs a repair. In this case, the nearest seam is along the sleeve. Rip a large segment of the seam, so that the jacket is comfortable to work with.

Lines.Text: turn the jacket inside out .
measure the width of the baffle you're working on . in this case , each baffle looks like it is two inches wide .
we are replacing two baffles , so we will need just over four inches of fabric to patch .

measure the length of the baffle ( along the baffle seam ) . in our case , the baffle length is nine inches , and since our repair is in the sleeve , we will double this to eighteen inches for the length of our scrap .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the jacket inside out. Measure the width of the baffle you're working on. In this case, each baffle looks like it is two inches wide. We are replacing two baffles, so we will need just over four inches of fabric to patch. Measure the length of the baffle (along the baffle seam). In our case, the baffle length is nine inches, and since our repair is in the sleeve, we will double this to eighteen inches for the length of our scrap.

Lines.Text: get a scrap of matching fabric to patch the baffle . make sure you have enough fabric to cover the area you measured in the previous step , with an inch or two extra in each direction .
we are using a piece of fabric that is slightly lighter than our jacket , so you can easily identify which areas we are working on .
fold one of the long edges of the fabric over so that it is straight .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a scrap of matching fabric to patch the baffle. Make sure you have enough fabric to cover the area you measured in the previous step, with an inch or two extra in each direction. We are using a piece of fabric that is slightly lighter than our jacket, so you can easily identify which areas we are working on. Fold one of the long edges of the fabric over so that it is straight.

Lines.Text: iron the fold into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Iron the fold into place.

Lines.Text: align the folded edge of the scrap along the outermost seam on the baffle you want to replace .
be sure the rough , folded-over fabric is between the baffle with the hole and the new scrap of fabric .
align the folded edge of the baffle with the seam , and pin it into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the folded edge of the scrap along the outermost seam on the baffle you want to replace. Be sure the rough, folded-over fabric is between the baffle with the hole and the new scrap of fabric. Align the folded edge of the baffle with the seam, and pin it into place.

Lines.Text: set the pinned piece into the sewing machine .

be sure to use the smallest needle you can find to patch this baffle . this will keep the new stitch from looking too prominent and help prevent the down from escaping through the new stitching holes .
sew directly over the old baffle seam . you will be sewing very close to the edge of the fold , just catching the fabric .
if youre working on a sleeve , make sure you only have one layer of the sleeve and that youre not sewing the entire sleeve shut .
go slowly , and guide the folded edge of the fabric directly over the old baffle seam . you may have to realign the folded edge of the fabric as you gothat's okay .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the pinned piece into the sewing machine. Be sure to use the smallest needle you can find to patch this baffle. This will keep the new stitch from looking too prominent and help prevent the down from escaping through the new stitching holes. Sew directly over the old baffle seam. You will be sewing very close to the edge of the fold, just catching the fabric. If you’re working on a sleeve, make sure you only have one layer of the sleeve and that you’re not sewing the entire sleeve shut. Go slowly, and guide the folded edge of the fabric directly over the old baffle seam. You may have to realign the folded edge of the fabric as you go—that's okay.

Lines.Text: while you're sewing , be sure to hold the sewing glossarysection_bias_tapebias tape ( which covered the seam edge ) out of the way so that it doesn't get caught in the seam .
continue to carefully sew the fold into place .
the fabric is very slippery , so be careful and take your time . judge the seam to your liking .
when you come to the end of the seam , sewing glossarysection_backstitchbackstitch to keep your thread in place .

Steps.Text_raw: While you're sewing, be sure to hold the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Bias_Tape|bias tape]] (which covered the seam edge) out of the way so that it doesn't get caught in the seam. Continue to carefully sew the fold into place. The fabric is very slippery, so be careful and take your time. Judge the seam to your liking. When you come to the end of the seam, [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Backstitch|backstitch]] to keep your thread in place.

Lines.Text: we are working with three baffle seams in total . you've already sewn one at the outer edge . skipping the baffle seam in the middle , pin the second fold into place on the seam at the other outer edge .
sew the second seam as you did the first .

Steps.Text_raw: We are working with three baffle seams in total. You've already sewn one at the outer edge. Skipping the baffle seam in the middle, pin the second fold into place on the seam at the other outer edge. Sew the second seam as you did the first.

Lines.Text: continue sewing .
when you are finished , your jacket should look like the second image .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue sewing. When you are finished, your jacket should look like the second image.

Lines.Text: turn the jacket right-side out again so you can see the original baffle stitching .
be sure to flip the bias tape out of the inside of the seam so it doesn't get caught as you continue to sew .
align your presser foot on top of the untouched , middle seam ( between the two seams you've already sewed ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the jacket right-side out again so you can see the original baffle stitching. Be sure to flip the bias tape out of the inside of the seam so it doesn't get caught as you continue to sew. Align your presser foot on top of the untouched, middle seam (between the two seams you've already sewed).

Lines.Text: sew directly over the original middle baffle stitching between the two seams you just made .
be sure to hold the bias tape out of the way .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew directly over the original middle baffle stitching between the two seams you just made. Be sure to hold the bias tape out of the way.

Lines.Text: trim off the excess fabric .

Steps.Text_raw: Trim off the excess fabric.

Lines.Text: for our repair of the sleeve , we need to realign the sleeve seam that we ripped .
pull the bias tape out of the way .
sew the sleeve seam closed , backstitching at the beginning and end of the seam .

Steps.Text_raw: For our repair of the sleeve, we need to realign the sleeve seam that we ripped. Pull the bias tape out of the way. Sew the sleeve seam closed, backstitching at the beginning and end of the seam.

Lines.Text: replace the bias tape over the completed sleeve seam .
adjust it so it sits correctly on both sides of the seam .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the bias tape over the completed sleeve seam. Adjust it so it sits correctly on both sides of the seam.

Lines.Text: sew the bias tape back on . make sure you sew as close to the inside edge of the bias tape as possible .
backstitch at both ends of the seam .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew the bias tape back on. Make sure you sew as close to the inside edge of the bias tape as possible. Backstitch at both ends of the seam.

Lines.Text: inspect your seams . make sure that everything is in place , clip your threads , and be very proud of yourself . that was a tough repair .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect your seams. Make sure that everything is in place, clip your threads, and be very proud of yourself. That was a tough repair.

Title: Patch a Patagonia Down Jacket with Repair Tape

Lines.Text: inspect the damage . clip any dangling threads , fabric , or feathers using small scissors . .
do not pull feathers out with your finger . pulling feathers encourages more feathers to come out the hole and makes the problem worse .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the damage. Clip any dangling threads, fabric, or feathers using small scissors. . Do not pull feathers out with your finger. Pulling feathers encourages more feathers to come out the hole and makes the problem worse.

Lines.Text: clean the fabric area that you are repairing with isopropyl alcohol prior to applying the patch . this will remove dirt and oil allowing the adhesive to bond well to the fabric . allow fabric to dry for a short period before adhering the patch

Steps.Text_raw: Clean the fabric area that you are repairing with Isopropyl alcohol  prior to applying  the patch. This will remove dirt and oil  allowing the adhesive to bond well to the fabric.  Allow fabric to dry for a short period before adhering the patch

Lines.Text: grab your repair tape .
flip the repair tape to the back side .
using a permanent marker , draw an oval slightly larger than the hole .
if you have a wide hole , you can use a rectangle , but be sure to round the edges . rounding the edges prevents the corners from getting caught and peeling up .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab your repair tape. Flip the repair tape to the back side. Using a permanent marker, draw an oval slightly larger than the hole. If you have a wide hole, you can use a rectangle, but be sure to round the edges. Rounding the edges prevents the corners from getting caught and peeling up.

Lines.Text: cut out your shape using scissors .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut out your shape using scissors.

Lines.Text: lay the shape over the hole to ensure that the patch is large enough . you want the patch to be reach the fabric on all sides with at least an 1 /8 of overlap .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the shape over the hole to ensure that the patch is large enough. You want the patch to be reach the fabric on all sides with at least an 1/8" of overlap.

Lines.Text: using your fingernail , or a pin , peel the backing off the repair tape , so that you only have the clear sticky layer .
be sure not to touch the sticky side , as this will gum up the tape and it will not stick well .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your fingernail, or a pin, peel the backing off the repair tape, so that you only have the clear sticky layer. Be sure not to touch the sticky side, as this will gum up the tape and it will not stick well.

Lines.Text: lay the tape over the hole and press the tape down with your finger .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the tape over the hole and press the tape down with your finger.

Lines.Text: use a fingernail or a spudger to work all of the air out of the tape , rubbing it and pressing down on it with a warm palm until it is well-adhered .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a fingernail or a spudger to work all of the air out of the tape, rubbing it  and pressing down on it with a warm palm until it is well-adhered.

Title: Installing A Main Zipper In Your Patagonia Down Jacket

Lines.Text: unzip the jacket and fold back the bottom corner .
identify the start of the seam that is holding the zipper in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Unzip the jacket and fold back the bottom corner. Identify the start of the seam that is holding the zipper in place.

Lines.Text: using a seam ripper , gently remove the stitches on the inside of the zipper .
be careful not to accidentally puncture or tear the jacket .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a seam ripper, gently remove the stitches on the inside of the zipper. Be careful not to accidentally puncture or tear the jacket.

Lines.Text: bend the zipper teeth away from the zipper webbing to make it easier to reach the stitches that hold the zipper and webbing together .
using the seam ripper , gently rip the seam between the zipper and zipper webbing .

Steps.Text_raw: Bend the zipper teeth away from the zipper webbing to make it easier to reach the stitches that hold the zipper and webbing together. Using the seam ripper, gently rip the seam between the zipper and zipper webbing.

Lines.Text: continue ripping the seam holding the zipper to the webbing until you come to the top of the seam .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue ripping the seam holding the zipper to the webbing until you come to the top of the seam.

Lines.Text: when you come to the fold in the zipper webbing , insert the seam ripper between the two layers of webbing , and gently pull the stitches out .

Steps.Text_raw: When you come to the fold in the zipper webbing, insert the seam ripper between the two layers of webbing, and gently pull the stitches out.

Lines.Text: the zipper should now be free from the jacket and can be discarded .

Steps.Text_raw: The zipper should now be free from the jacket and can be discarded.

Lines.Text: identify where the zipper flap is still sewn into the jacket . use the seam ripper to free the zipper flap from the jacket . the yellow rectangle in the photos above will help you identify the zipper flap .
be careful not to damage the jacket with the seam ripper as you free the webbing .

Steps.Text_raw: Identify where the zipper flap is still sewn into the jacket. Use the seam ripper to free the zipper flap from the jacket. The yellow rectangle in the photos above will help you identify the zipper flap. Be careful not to damage the jacket with the seam ripper as you free the webbing.

Lines.Text: lay the jacket flat and measure from the base of the zipper to the collar , along the seam you just removed . in our case we measured 27 inches .
the jacket should be flat , so you get an accurate measurement .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the jacket flat and measure from the base of the zipper to the collar, along the seam you just removed. In our case we measured 27 inches. The jacket should be flat, so you get an accurate measurement.

Lines.Text: lay out your new zipper on a flat surface and use the measurement you recorded in the step above , starting from the zipper box , or the bottom of the zipper .
mark the measurement with tailor's chalk .
pull the zipper slider back behind the mark you just made .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay out your new zipper on a flat surface and use the measurement you recorded in the step above, starting from the zipper box, or the bottom of the zipper. Mark the measurement with tailor's chalk. Pull the zipper slider back behind the mark you just made.

Lines.Text: measure one inch beyond where you just marked and make a second mark with tailors chalk .

Steps.Text_raw: Measure one inch beyond where you just marked and make a second mark with tailor’s chalk.

Lines.Text: cut the zipper between the teeth at the second mark you made .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the zipper between the teeth at the second mark you made.

Lines.Text: use end nipper pliers to remove the teeth of the zipper between the two marks .
use needle-nose pliers to remove all the leftover bits of the teeth from the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Use end nipper pliers to remove the teeth of the zipper between the two marks. Use needle-nose pliers to remove all the leftover bits of the teeth from the zipper.

Lines.Text: take a zipper stop and align it , posts down , just beyond the last remaining zipper tooth .
crimp the zipper stop onto the zipper using pliers .

Steps.Text_raw: Take a zipper stop and align it, posts down, just beyond the last remaining zipper tooth. Crimp the zipper stop onto the zipper using pliers.

Lines.Text: fold the excess zipper tape away from the teeth at a slight angle .
sew the toothless end of the zipper down , backstitching to hold it in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the excess zipper tape away from the teeth at a slight angle. Sew the toothless end of the zipper down, backstitching to hold it in place.

Lines.Text: align the toothless edge of the zipper with the inside serged edge of the zipper webbing .
the serged edge is the one with the zig-zag stitching .
fold the top of the webbing down over the sewn zipper tape .
you can pin the zipper and webbing in place for more stability .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the toothless edge of the zipper with the inside serged edge of the zipper webbing. The serged edge is the one with the zig-zag stitching. Fold the top of the webbing down over the sewn zipper tape. You can pin the zipper and webbing in place for more stability.

Lines.Text: align the zipper and webbing in the sewing machine so that the zipper teeth are along the edge of the presser foot .
sew a few stitches , removing pins before you come to them .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the zipper and webbing in the sewing machine so that the zipper teeth are along the edge of the presser foot. Sew a few stitches, removing pins before you come to them.

Lines.Text: sew along the edge of the zipper teeth , making sure that the zipper and webbing stay aligned .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew along the edge of the zipper teeth, making sure that the zipper and webbing stay aligned.

Lines.Text: reinsert the zipper and webbing into the jacket , aligning the edge of the jacket fabric with the zipper teeth .

Steps.Text_raw: Reinsert the zipper and webbing into the jacket, aligning the edge of the jacket fabric with the zipper teeth.

Lines.Text: while holding the zipper in place , move the fabric underneath the zipper out of the way so youre only sewing the zipper to one layer of fabric .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the zipper in place, move the fabric underneath the zipper out of the way so you’re only sewing the zipper to one layer of fabric.

Lines.Text: install the zipper foot into your sewing machine .
align the jacket and zipper in the sewing machine .
be sure that there is no fabric behind the zipper webbing before you sew .

Steps.Text_raw: Install the zipper foot into your sewing machine. Align the jacket and zipper in the sewing machine. Be sure that there is no fabric behind the zipper webbing before you sew.

Lines.Text: check your alignment and begin sewing , guiding the fabric along the zipper teeth .
go slowly , re-aligning the fabric as you go .

Steps.Text_raw: Check your alignment and begin sewing, guiding the fabric along the zipper teeth. Go slowly, re-aligning the fabric as you go.

Lines.Text: continue sewing and re-aligning the zipper as you proceed along the full length of the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue sewing and re-aligning the zipper as you proceed along the full length of the zipper.

Lines.Text: when you reach the end of the zipper , backstitch to hold your stitches in place and remove the jacket from the sewing machine .

Steps.Text_raw: When you reach the end of the zipper, backstitch to hold your stitches in place and remove the jacket from the sewing machine.

Lines.Text: align the inside jacket fabric along the backside of the webbing .
try to align the stitch holes directly over the stitches you just sewed .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the inside jacket fabric along the backside of the webbing. Try to align the stitch holes directly over the stitches you just sewed.

Lines.Text: align the jacket in the sewing machine , with the zipper webbing facing up .
holding the inside fabric of the jack in place , sew directly over the original stitching .
go slowly , re-aligning the fabric as you go .
clip the threads , and admire your work !
repeat this guide , ironing the webbing when youre finished , to install the other side of the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the jacket in the sewing machine, with the zipper webbing facing up. Holding the inside fabric of the jack in place, sew directly over the original stitching. Go slowly, re-aligning the fabric as you go. Clip the threads, and admire your work! Repeat this guide, ironing the webbing when you’re finished, to install the other side of the zipper.

Subject: Main Zipper

Title: Installing a Zipper in a Patagonia Fleece Jacket

Lines.Text: lay your jacket face-up onto a flat surface like a table . unzip the zipper as much as possible .
fold open the bottom corner of the jacket .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your jacket face-up onto a flat surface like a table. Unzip the zipper as much as possible. Fold open the bottom corner of the jacket.

Lines.Text: sewing glossarysection_seam_ripperrip the seam that holds the zipper in place . this is the outside seam of the two rows of stitching .

Steps.Text_raw: [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Seam_Ripper|Rip the seam]] that holds the zipper in place. This is the outside seam of the two rows of stitching.

Lines.Text: start ripping the inside sewing glossarysection_seamseam .
rip only a few of the stitches .
be sure to avoid ripping the serged edge . to do this , start the blade pointing away from the serge seam .

Steps.Text_raw: Start ripping the inside [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Seam|seam]]. Rip only a few of the stitches. Be sure to avoid ripping the serged edge. To do this, start the blade pointing away from the serge seam.

Lines.Text: after you have ripped a few stitches , fold the jacket closed again .
pull the zipper webbing away from the teeth of the zipper .
rip the stitches holding the webbing to the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: After you have ripped a few stitches, fold the jacket closed again. Pull the zipper webbing away from the teeth of the zipper. Rip the stitches holding the webbing to the zipper.

Lines.Text: at the top of the zipper there will be an area where the collar is folded back over itself . rip out the outermost seam holding the zipper webbing in place .
both the zipper webbing and zipper should now be free from the jacket .
repeat steps 1-5 on the other side of the zipper . the second side may or may not have webbing .

Steps.Text_raw: At the top of the zipper there will be an area where the collar is folded back over itself. Rip out the outermost seam holding the zipper webbing in place. Both the zipper webbing and zipper should now be free from the jacket. Repeat steps 1-5 on the other side of the zipper. The second side may or may not have webbing.

Lines.Text: lay your jacket out , holding it to full length but not stretched . measure from the top of the collar to waist .
sewing glossarysection_measuring_tapemeasure the same length on your zipper from the zipper stop up . mark this with tailors chalk .
measure two inches above that line and make a second mark with your tailors chalk .
cut the zipper at the first mark you made . be sure to cut between the teeth of the zipper to preserve your scissors .
be sure that the zipper slider is below your first mark so you don't cut it off !

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your jacket out, holding it to full length but not stretched. Measure from the top of the collar to waist. [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Measuring_Tape|Measure]] the same length on your zipper from the zipper stop up. Mark this with tailor’s chalk. Measure two inches above that line and make a second mark with your tailor’s chalk. Cut the zipper at the first mark you made. Be sure to cut between the teeth of the zipper to preserve your scissors. Be sure that the zipper slider is below your first mark so you don't cut it off!

Lines.Text: use end nipper pliers to cut off all of the zipper teeth above the first mark .
cut the teeth in half , and then remove the back half with your fingers .
remove two teeth below the mark on one side .
repeat this step on the other side of the zipper , removing three teeth below the mark instead of two .

Steps.Text_raw: Use end nipper pliers to cut off all of the zipper teeth above the first mark. Cut the teeth in half, and then remove the back half with your fingers. Remove two teeth below the mark on one side. Repeat this step on the other side of the zipper, removing three teeth below the mark instead of two.

Lines.Text: place the zipper stop directly above the last tooth on the zipper . be sure you get all the way around the zipper .
crimp the zipper stop into place using pliers .
repeat this step on the second side of the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the zipper stop directly above the last tooth on the zipper. Be sure you get all the way around the zipper. Crimp the zipper stop into place using pliers. Repeat this step on the second side of the zipper.

Lines.Text: take the side of the zipper that had webbing , and fold the excess zipper sewing glossarysection_bias_tapetape on the end of the zipper away from the zipper teeth at a slight angle .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the side of the zipper that had webbing, and fold the excess zipper  [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Bias_Tape|tape]] on the end of the zipper away from the zipper teeth at a slight angle.

Lines.Text: place the folded zipper end into the sewing machine .
tack the fold into place with a few stitches .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the folded zipper end into the sewing machine. Tack the fold into place with a few stitches.

Lines.Text: clip the threads on the zipper .
repeat steps 9-11 on the other side of the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Clip the threads on the zipper. Repeat steps 9-11 on the other side of the zipper.

Lines.Text: take the side of the zipper that had the webbing , and lay it back into the webbing , aligning the zipper tape edge along the serged edge of the webbing .
place the top of the zipper in the crease of the fold of the webbing at the collar .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the side of the zipper that had the webbing, and lay it back into the webbing, aligning the zipper tape edge along the serged edge of the webbing. Place the top of the zipper in the crease of the fold of the webbing at the collar.

Lines.Text: fold the top of the zipper webbing over the zipper at the crease of the collar .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the top of the zipper webbing over the zipper at the crease of the collar.

Lines.Text: pin the folded zipper webbing in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Pin the folded zipper webbing in place.

Lines.Text: pin the length of the zipper to the webbing , making sure that the zipper tape edge is still aligned with the serged edge of the webbing .
the serged edge is the edge with the , overlock , or zigzag stitching .

Steps.Text_raw: Pin the length of the zipper to the webbing, making sure that the zipper tape edge is still aligned with the serged edge of the webbing. The serged edge is the edge with the, overlock, or zigzag stitching.

Lines.Text: position the webbing and zipper in the sewing machine 1 /4 of an inch from the zipper teeth on the side of the zipper tape .
sew the zipper onto the webbing .

Steps.Text_raw: Position the webbing and zipper in the sewing machine 1/4 of an inch from the zipper teeth on the side of the zipper tape. Sew the zipper onto the webbing.

Lines.Text: while youre sewing , remove the pins as you come to them . running them over with your machine may break your needle .

Steps.Text_raw: While you’re sewing, remove the pins as you come to them. Running them over with your machine may break your needle.

Lines.Text: sewing glossarysection_backstitchbackstitch at the end of the zipper to prevent the seam from unraveling .
cut the threads , and free the zipper and webbing from the sewing machine .

Steps.Text_raw: [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Backstitch|Backstitch]] at the end of the zipper to prevent the seam from unraveling. Cut the threads, and free the zipper and webbing from the sewing machine.

Lines.Text: take the jacket collar and open the folded section that you ripped out in step 6.
sandwich the top of the zipper and webbing in between the two layers as you would see it when it is finished .
align the top of the webbing with the border between the fleece and the start of the same type of fabric as the webbing , about 1 /4 inch below the edge of the collar .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the jacket collar and open the folded section that you ripped out in step 6. Sandwich the top of the zipper and webbing in between the two layers as you would see it when it is finished. Align the top of the webbing with the border between the fleece and the start of the same type of fabric as the webbing, about 1/4 inch below the edge of the collar.

Lines.Text: fold the backside of the collar fabric over the webbing that covers the zipper seam .
holding the backside of the collar fabric in place , turn the collar back to the front side .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the backside of the collar fabric over the webbing that covers the zipper seam. Holding the backside of the collar fabric in place, turn the collar back to the front side.

Lines.Text: still holding the zipper and webbing between the two layers of collar fabric , pin the layers in place .
continue pinning the webbing and zipper to the inside of the jacket , along the seam you originally ripped .

Steps.Text_raw: Still holding the zipper and webbing between the two layers of collar fabric, pin the layers in place. Continue pinning the webbing and zipper to the inside of the jacket, along the seam you originally ripped.

Lines.Text: when you come to the jacket's waist , sandwich the webbing and zipper between the folded edge at the waist .

Steps.Text_raw: When you come to the jacket's waist, sandwich the webbing and zipper between the folded edge at the waist.

Lines.Text: change the sewing glossarysection_presser_footpresser foot to the sewing glossarysection_zipper_footzipper foot .
sew the edge of the fleece to the jacket as close to the edge as possible .
be sure to backstitch at each end of the seam .

Steps.Text_raw: Change the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Presser_Foot|presser foot]] to the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Zipper_Foot|zipper foot]]. Sew the edge of the fleece to the jacket as close to the edge as possible. Be sure to backstitch at each end of the seam.

Lines.Text: sewing glossarysection_topstitchtopstitch the fleece to the zipper 1 /4 inch from the zipper .
backstitch at both ends of the seam .

Steps.Text_raw: [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Topstitch|Topstitch]] the fleece to the zipper 1/4 inch from the zipper. Backstitch at both ends of the seam.

Lines.Text: sandwich the second side of the zipper in the collar just as you did the first side . this side will not have webbing .
align the zipper at the waist of the jacket , sandwiching the zipper into the waist as necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Sandwich the second side of the zipper in the collar just as you did the first side. This side will not have webbing. Align the zipper at the waist of the jacket, sandwiching the zipper into the waist as necessary.

Lines.Text: align the second side of the zipper at the border of the fleece ( or any other fabric like a wind resistant material ) about a quarter of an inch below the top edge of the collar , as you did on the previous side .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the second side of the zipper at the border of the fleece (or any other fabric like a wind resistant material) about a quarter of an inch below the top edge of the collar, as you did on the previous side.

Lines.Text: check that the zipper is sandwiched in the collar as on the other side .
pin the second side of the zipper in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Check that the zipper is sandwiched in the collar as on the other side. Pin the second side of the zipper in place.

Lines.Text: replace the zipper foot in your machine .
as before , sew the zipper into place very close to the edge .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the zipper foot in your machine. As before, sew the zipper into place very close to the edge.

Lines.Text: topstitch the second side as before .
clip threads , check out your work , and give yourself a pat on the back .

Steps.Text_raw: Topstitch the second side as before. Clip threads, check out your work, and give yourself a pat on the back.

Subject: Zipper

Title: Repairing the Stitching on your Patagonia Nano Puff ® Jacket

Lines.Text: examine the damaged area of your jacket . in our case we have a few missing stitches along a single line of stitching .
select thread that matches the fabric color on the outside of the jacket and guide .
select thread that matches the fabric color on the lining of your jacket and guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damaged area of your jacket. In our case we have a few missing stitches along a single line of stitching. Select thread that matches the fabric color on the outside of the jacket and [guide|19463|load it into the sewing machine]. Select thread that matches the fabric color on the lining of your jacket and [guide|19460|load it into the bobbin of your sewing machine].

Lines.Text: set your sewing machine stitch length to about 3.
clip the extra thread off of your jacket .

Steps.Text_raw: Set your sewing machine stitch length to about 3. Clip the extra thread off of your jacket.

Lines.Text: align the jacket in the sewing machine at a distance of roughly five stitches before the missing stitching .
be sure that the jacket is unzipped and that you only have one layer of the jacket , including the lining , in the sewing machine . sewing two layers together will sew the jacket shut .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the jacket in the sewing machine at a distance of roughly five stitches before the missing stitching. Be sure that the jacket is unzipped and that you only have one layer of the jacket, including the lining, in the sewing machine. Sewing two layers together will sew the jacket shut.

Lines.Text: sink the needle , being sure that it aligns with the stitching .
sew forward a few stitches and then backstitch to hold your stitches in place .
sew along the holes where the stitching used to be .

Steps.Text_raw: Sink the needle, being sure that it aligns with the stitching. Sew forward a few stitches and then backstitch to hold your stitches in place. Sew along the holes where the stitching used to be.

Lines.Text: continue sewing until you overlap five of the remaining stitches .
backstitch to hold your stitches in place .
clip any threads to free the garment from the sewing machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue sewing until you overlap five of the remaining stitches. Backstitch to hold your stitches in place. Clip any threads to free the garment from the sewing machine.

Title: Repairing Patagonia Jacket with a Shaped Baffle

Lines.Text: examine the damage on your jacket , cutting off any loose threads and freeing any debris
our garment has holes in two of the baffle segments , but we will just work on one for this guide .
choose some patch fabric .
why not choose a fun color ? we did .
select thread that matches your patch fabric , and guide .
select thread that matches the lining of your jacket , and guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damage on your jacket, cutting off any loose threads and freeing any debris Our garment has holes in two of the baffle segments, but we will just work on one for this guide. Choose some patch fabric. Why not choose a fun color? We did. Select thread that matches your patch fabric, and [guide|19463|load it into your sewing machine]. Select thread that matches the lining of your jacket, and [guide|19460|load it into the bobbin of your sewing machine].

Lines.Text: trace the shape of your baffle onto some cardstock or heavy paper .
cut out the shape of the baffle ; this will be your template .
place the template over the baffle to ensure that the shape and size of your template is correct .

Steps.Text_raw: Trace the shape of your baffle onto some cardstock or heavy paper. Cut out the shape of the baffle; this will be your template. Place the template over the baffle to ensure that the shape and size of your template is correct.

Lines.Text: set your iron to the appropriate settingin our case , nylonand guide to smooth out any wrinkles .
position the template on the patch fabric , leaving about ¼ or ½ inch of extra fabric around the edges .
cut out the patch , leaving 1 /4 or 1 /2 inch of extra fabric around each side of the template .

Steps.Text_raw: Set your iron to the appropriate setting—in our case, nylon—and [guide|10273|iron your patch fabric] to smooth out any wrinkles. Position the template on the patch fabric, leaving about ¼ or ½ inch of extra fabric around the edges. Cut out the patch, leaving 1/4 or 1/2 inch of extra fabric around each side of the template.

Lines.Text: fold the edge of the fabric over , creating a fold at the edge of the template .
carefully hold the fabric in place and iron it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Fold the edge of the fabric over, creating a fold at the edge of the template. Carefully hold the fabric in place and iron it down.

Lines.Text: work around the template , folding each side in , and ironing it into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Work around the template, folding each side in, and ironing it into place.

Lines.Text: slide the template out of the patch .
refold along the creases you previously ironed .
turn the patch over so that the right-side , or the side that will be showing , is up and press it .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the template out of the patch. Refold along the creases you previously ironed. Turn the patch over so that the right-side, or the side that will be showing, is up and press it.

Lines.Text: align the patch with the baffle , exactly as you want it to appear when you are done .
slide the garment into the sewing machine , repositioning the patch if necessary .
to prevent the insulation from leaking through the stitches , fir your sewing machine with the smallest needle available .
sink the needle to hold the patch into place .
do not pin the patch , as this will create unnecessary holes where down can escape .
holding the patch in place sew directly over the edge of your patch .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the patch with the baffle, exactly as you want it to appear when you are done. Slide the garment into the sewing machine, repositioning the patch if necessary. To prevent the insulation from leaking through the stitches, fir your sewing machine with the smallest needle available. Sink the needle to hold the patch into place. Do not pin the patch, as this will create unnecessary holes where down can escape. Holding the patch in place sew directly over the edge of your patch.

Lines.Text: when you come to the corner of your patch , sink the needle .
lift the presser foot , leaving the needle in the fabric , and gently turn the fabric 90 degrees , aligning it with the edge of the patch .
drop the presser foot and continue sewing along the second edge of the patch .
be sure to hold the patch in place as you sew .

Steps.Text_raw: When you come to the corner of your patch, sink the needle. Lift the presser foot, leaving the needle in the fabric, and gently turn the fabric 90 degrees, aligning it with the edge of the patch. Drop the presser foot and continue sewing along the second edge of the patch. Be sure to hold the patch in place as you sew.

Lines.Text: as you did with the first corner , sink the needle , lift the presser foot , and rotate the garment .
drop the presser foot and continue sewing on the third edge of the patch .

Steps.Text_raw: As you did with the first corner, sink the needle, lift the presser foot, and rotate the garment. Drop the presser foot and continue sewing on the third edge of the patch.

Lines.Text: repeat step nine for the last corner , and sew the final edge of the patch in place .
backstitch when you come to the end of the patch .

Steps.Text_raw: Repeat step nine for the last corner, and sew the final edge of the patch in place. Backstitch when you come to the end of the patch.

Lines.Text: lift the needle and presser foot , freeing the garment from the sewing machine .
clip any threads , and admire your work !

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the needle and presser foot, freeing the garment from the sewing machine. Clip any threads, and admire your work!

Title: Patch your Patagonia Nano Puff ® Jacket with Repair Tape

Lines.Text: inspect the damage on your jacket . clip any dangling threads or fabric using small scissors .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the damage on your jacket. Clip any dangling threads or fabric using small scissors.

Lines.Text: grab your repair tape .
flip the repair tape to the back side .
using a permanent marker , draw an oval slightly larger than the hole .
if you have a wide hole , you can use a rectangle , but be sure to round the edges . rounding the edges prevents the corners from getting caught and peeling up .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab your repair tape. Flip the repair tape to the back side. Using a permanent marker, draw an oval slightly larger than the hole. If you have a wide hole, you can use a rectangle, but be sure to round the edges. Rounding the edges prevents the corners from getting caught and peeling up.

Lines.Text: cut out your shape using scissors .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut out your shape using scissors.

Lines.Text: using your fingernail , or a pin , peel the backing off the tenacious tape , so that you only have the clear sticky layer .
be sure not to touch the sticky side of the tape as this will gum up the tape and it wont stick well .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your fingernail, or a pin, peel the backing off the tenacious tape, so that you only have the clear sticky layer. Be sure not to touch the sticky side of the tape as this will gum up the tape and it won’t stick well.

Lines.Text: lay the tape over the hole and press the tape down with your finger .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the tape over the hole and press the tape down with your finger.

Lines.Text: use a fingernail or spudger to work out all of the air bubbles under the tape . continue rubbing the tape until it is well-adhered .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a fingernail or spudger to work out all of the air bubbles under the tape. Continue rubbing the tape until it is well-adhered.

Title: Satin Stitch a Tear in Your Shirt

Lines.Text: examine the tear and the surrounding fabric .
clip any loose threads to keep them from getting caught in the new stitching .
select a coordinating color of thread and guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the tear and the surrounding fabric. Clip any loose threads to keep them from getting caught in the new stitching. Select a coordinating color of thread and [guide|19463|thread the sewing machine].

Lines.Text: adjust the sewing machine to a stitch-width of two or three .
stitch-width controls the sideways distance of the stitch , so if you feel you need a little more width , three is acceptable .
every sewing machine is different , so refer to your sewing machine manual to find the stitch width adjustment on your machine .

be sure your sewing machine is fitted with a wide-mouthed pressor foot , as opposed to one with a small round hole . when the sewing machine does a satin stitch , it will bump into the the pressor foot and break if there is not a wide enough opening .

Steps.Text_raw: Adjust the sewing machine to a stitch-width of two or three. Stitch-width controls the sideways distance of the stitch, so if you feel you need a little more width, three is acceptable. Every sewing machine is different, so refer to your sewing machine manual to find the stitch width adjustment on your machine. Be sure your sewing machine is fitted with a wide-mouthed pressor foot, as opposed to one with a small round hole. When the sewing machine does a satin stitch, it will bump into the the pressor foot and break if there is not a wide enough opening.

Lines.Text: set the sewing machine stitch length down to just above zero .
stitch length controls how far forward the sewing machine advances with each stitch . satin stitches should be very tight , which is why we want this number very close to zero .
every sewing machine is different , so refer to your sewing machine manual to find the stitch length adjustment on your machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the sewing machine stitch length down to just above zero. Stitch length controls how far forward the sewing machine advances with each stitch. Satin stitches should be very tight, which is why we want this number very close to zero. Every sewing machine is different, so refer to your sewing machine manual to find the stitch length adjustment on your machine.

Lines.Text: if the fabric youre repairing is gauzy or thin , you can add a small scrap of interfacing or scrap fabric on the backside of your rip or tear . most of the time this isnt necessary .
align the fabric in the sewing machine about half an inch before the rip or tear .
lower the pressor foot and begin sewing , guiding the machine over the tear .

Steps.Text_raw: If the fabric you’re repairing is gauzy or thin, you can add a small scrap of interfacing or scrap fabric on the backside of your rip or tear. Most of the time this isn’t necessary. Align the fabric in the sewing machine about half an inch before the rip or tear. Lower the pressor foot and begin sewing, guiding the machine over the tear.

Lines.Text: sew about half an inch past the end of the slit .
lift the presser foot and clip the threads to free the garment .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew about half an inch past the end of the slit. Lift the presser foot and clip the threads to free the garment.

Lines.Text: trim any extra threads .
admire your handiwork .

Steps.Text_raw: Trim any extra threads. Admire your handiwork.

Subject: Tear

Title: Installing a Professor Patch on a Patagonia Sweater

Lines.Text: lay your sweater flat on a work surface , damage side up .
measure the length of the hole .
measure the width of the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your sweater flat on a work surface, damage side up. Measure the length of the hole. Measure the width of the hole.

Lines.Text: on a piece of paper , mark the endpoints of a line that measures the length of the hole , plus one inch .
mark the center of the two endpoints .
from the center , turn the measuring tape 90 degrees . mark the endpoints of a line that measures the width of the hole , plus one inch .

Steps.Text_raw: On a piece of paper, mark the endpoints of a line that measures the length of the hole, plus one inch. Mark the center of the two endpoints. From the center, turn the measuring tape 90 degrees. Mark the endpoints of a line that measures the width of the hole, plus one inch.

Lines.Text: sketch a curve connecting the endpoints of the length and width .
draw a straight line connecting the endpoints of the width , going though the center point .
fold the paper in half on the straight line .
cut along the curved line . the piece you have just cut out will be your pattern .

Steps.Text_raw: Sketch a curve connecting the endpoints of the length and width. Draw a straight line connecting the endpoints of the width, going though the center point. Fold the paper in half on the straight line. Cut along the curved line. The piece you have just cut out will be your pattern.

Lines.Text: lay your pattern over the hole to verify that it is the correct size and shape .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your pattern over the hole to verify that it is the correct size and shape.

Lines.Text: lay your pattern over the piece of fabric youve choosen to use as a patch .

it is important to choose a fabric that is only slightly heavier than your sweater , such as corduroy or a felted sweater . anything heavier , such as denim or leather , may cause the sweater to tear .
to felt a sweater , simply put a 100 wool sweater through the washer and dryer . when it comes out , the sweater should be shrunken and have a very tight weave .
pin your pattern piece onto your patch fabric .
if you double up the patch fabric before you pin you will get two identical patches , one for each side .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your pattern over the piece of fabric you’ve choosen to use as a patch. It is important to choose a fabric that is only slightly heavier than your sweater, such as corduroy or a felted sweater. Anything heavier, such as denim or leather, may cause the sweater to tear. To felt a sweater, simply put a 100% wool sweater through the washer and dryer. When it comes out, the sweater should be shrunken and have a very tight weave. Pin your pattern piece onto your patch fabric. If you double up the patch fabric before you pin you will get two identical patches, one for each side.

Lines.Text: using fabric scissors , cut around the pattern piece .
inspect the patch , going back to clean up any rough edges with scissors .

Steps.Text_raw: Using fabric scissors, cut around the pattern piece. Inspect the patch, going back to clean up any rough edges with scissors.

Lines.Text: lay the patch over the hole , positioning it where you would like it to be .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the patch over the hole, positioning it where you would like it to be.

Lines.Text: pin the patch into place .
only pin the patch to the top layer of the sleeve fabric ; if you pin and sew them both , you will sew the sleeve shut .

Steps.Text_raw: Pin the patch into place. Only pin the patch to the top layer of the sleeve fabric; if you pin and sew them both, you will sew the sleeve shut.

Lines.Text: insert a ballpoint needle into your sewing machine .
each sewing machine is a little bit different , so check your user's manual if you aren't sure how to change your needle .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert a ballpoint needle into your sewing machine. Each sewing machine is a little bit different, so check your user's manual if you aren't sure how to change your needle.

Lines.Text: slide the sleeve over the arm of your sewing machine , just like youd put the sleeve over your own arm .

you may need to remove the table from your sewing machine to allow the sweater sleeve to slide over the sewing machine arm . check you sewing machine manual for specific instructions on your machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the sleeve over the arm of your sewing machine, just like you’d put the sleeve over your own arm.
