You may need to remove the table from your sewing machine to allow the sweater sleeve to slide over the sewing machine arm. Check you sewing machine manual for specific instructions on your machine.

Lines.Text: align the very edge of the patch with the needle .
sew around the edge of the patch , turning the sleeve as you go .
for a more stable patch , use zig-zag or guide .
sew until you come all the way around , retracing your first stitches .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the very edge of the patch with the needle. Sew around the edge of the patch, turning the sleeve as you go. For a more stable patch, use zig-zag or [guide|12424|satin stitch]. Sew until you come all the way around, retracing your first stitches.

Lines.Text: slide the sleeve off the arm of your sewing machine .
clip any loose threads .
repeat on the other sleeve if you want symmetrical professor patches .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the sleeve off the arm of your sewing machine. Clip any loose threads. Repeat on the other sleeve if you want symmetrical professor patches.

Subject: Professor Patch

Lines.Text: examine the damage cut off any long threads and clean off any debris .
grab your iron-on patch .
we are using a contrasting patch for visibility , but you may want something that matches with your jeans or a fun contrasting color .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damage – cut off any long threads and clean off any debris. Grab your iron-on patch. We are using a contrasting patch for visibility, but you may want something that matches with your jeans or a fun contrasting color.

Lines.Text: preheat your iron according to the recommended settings found on the packaging information included with the patch .
take a scrap of denim and place it inside the pant leg , beneath the hole .
this scrap material will keep your patch from sticking the front of your jeans to the back , which would effectively seal the leg opening shut ( not a good thing . . . )

Steps.Text_raw: Preheat your iron according to the recommended settings found on the packaging information included with the patch. Take a scrap of denim and place it inside the pant leg, beneath the hole. This scrap material will keep your patch from sticking the front of your jeans to the back, which would effectively seal the leg opening shut (not a good thing...)

Lines.Text: measure the length and width of the hole in your jeans , including any damaged area around the hole .
in our case the hole is about 1.5 inches by 2 inches .

Steps.Text_raw: Measure the length and width of the hole in your jeans, including any damaged area around the hole. In our case the hole is about 1.5 inches by 2 inches.

Lines.Text: add at least a half-inch in both directions to get your final patch measurements .
mark your final patch measurements on the patch with tailors chalk .

Steps.Text_raw: Add at least a half-inch in both directions to get your final patch measurements. Mark your final patch measurements on the patch with tailor’s chalk.

Lines.Text: cut the patch along your marks .
round the corners of the patch , to prevent them from peeling up .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the patch along your marks. Round the corners of the patch, to prevent them from peeling up.

Lines.Text: lay your cut patch over the hole and position it where you want it .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your cut patch over the hole and position it where you want it.

Lines.Text: iron the patch according to the package instructions , usually from between 30-45 seconds . keep the iron moving and try to apply even heat to the whole patch .

Steps.Text_raw: Iron the patch according to the package instructions, usually from between 30-45 seconds. Keep the iron moving and try to apply even heat to the whole patch.

Lines.Text: run your finger around the edge of the patch to ensue that all the edges are completely bonded to your jeans .

Steps.Text_raw: Run your finger around the edge of the patch to ensue that all the edges are completely bonded to your jeans.

Lines.Text: turn the pant leg inside out .
gently try and lift the scrap of fabric from the inside of the pant leg .
if the scrap comes off , you no longer need it .
if the scrap is held firmly in place by the patch , simply trim away the excess fabric from where the scrap is adhered with your scissors , leaving the remaining scrap in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the pant leg inside out. Gently try and lift the scrap of fabric from the inside of the pant leg. If the scrap comes off, you no longer need it. If the scrap is held firmly in place by the patch, simply trim away the excess fabric from where the scrap is adhered with your scissors, leaving the remaining scrap in place.

Title: Installing a Plastic Snap Using a Hand Press

Lines.Text: get a new cap .
get a new stud .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a new cap. Get a new stud.

Lines.Text: measure the diameter of the cap and socket to make sure they are the correct size .
there are two common sizes of snap , as pictured here . be sure that you have the correct one .

Steps.Text_raw: Measure the diameter of the cap and socket to make sure they are the correct size. There are two common sizes of snap, as pictured here. Be sure that you have the correct one.

Lines.Text: insert the cap , rounded side down , into the cap fitting for the hand press . the shaft of the cap should face out .
the cap fitting is marked orange .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the cap, rounded side down, into the cap fitting for the hand press. The shaft of the cap should face out. The cap fitting is marked orange.

Lines.Text: insert the stud into the stud fitting for the hand press . the widest part of the stud should be facing out . when seated correctly , the stud should snap into place and sit in the fitting without being held .
the stud fitting is marked green .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the stud into the stud fitting for the hand press. The widest part of the stud should be facing out. When seated correctly, the stud should snap into place and sit in the fitting without being held. The stud fitting is marked green.

Lines.Text: insert the cap fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press .
the cap fitting is marked orange .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the cap fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press. The cap fitting is marked orange.

Lines.Text: insert the stud fitting into the upper fitting holder of the hand press .
the stud fitting is marked green .
insert the fitting as far as it will go , so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting .
tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the stud fitting . tighten the screw about a 1 /4 turn past finger-tight .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the stud fitting into the upper fitting holder of the hand press. The stud fitting is marked green. Insert the fitting as far as it will go, so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting. Tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the stud fitting. Tighten the screw about a 1/4 turn past finger-tight.

Lines.Text: slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings .
the fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum .
if there is a gap in the fittings , adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings. The fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum. If there is a gap in the fittings, adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch.

Lines.Text: mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap .
align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the cap .
if the fabric is not laying flat , have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap .
the cap is on the bottom of the press . be sure that you place your fabric face down , so that the cap is on the correct side .

Steps.Text_raw: Mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap. Align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the cap. If the fabric is not laying flat, have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap. The cap is on the bottom of the press. Be sure that you place your fabric face down, so that the cap is on the correct side.

Lines.Text: with the fabric aligned , pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion .
setting a plastic snap requires little force . you will need to pull hard enough to get the press to its maximum range , but not beyond that .

Steps.Text_raw: With the fabric aligned, pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion. Setting a plastic snap requires little force. You will need to pull hard enough to get the press to its maximum range, but not beyond that.

Lines.Text: release the handle of the hand press , and remove the fabric .

inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric . when you inspect the stud side you should see that the nose of the cap has been pressed into a ring ; this is what holds the snap parts together .
if the snap is not set all the way , reinsert it into the hand press , aligning it as it was before , and repeat guide of this guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Release the handle of the hand press, and remove the fabric. Inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric. When you inspect the stud side you should see that the nose of the cap has been pressed into a ring; this is what holds the snap parts together. If the snap is not set all the way, reinsert it into the hand press, aligning it as it was before, and repeat [guide|16022|step 9|stepid=50175] of this guide.

Lines.Text: get a new cap .
get a new socket .

you will want the color to match on your componentswe are using different colors to illustrate that this is a different component than before . if the snap you are replacing has colors on the front and back that differ from each other , then try to match those colors .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a new cap. Get a new socket. You will want the color to match on your components—we are using different colors to illustrate that this is a different component than before. If the snap you are replacing has colors on the front and back that differ from each other, then try to match those colors.

Lines.Text: insert the cap , rounded side down , into the cap fitting for the hand press . the shaft of the cap should face out .
the cap fitting is marked orange .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the cap, rounded side down, into the cap fitting for the hand press. The shaft of the cap should face out. The cap fitting is marked orange.

Lines.Text: insert the socket into the socket fitting for the hand press . the widest part of the socket should be facing towards the fitting . when seated correctly , the socket should snap into place and sit in the fitting without being held .
the socket fitting is marked purple .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the socket into the socket fitting for the hand press. The widest part of the socket should be facing towards the fitting. When seated correctly, the socket should snap into place and sit in the fitting without being held. The socket fitting is marked purple.

Lines.Text: insert the cap fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press .
the cap fitting is marked orange .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the cap fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press. The cap fitting is marked orange.

Lines.Text: insert the socket fitting into the upper fitting holder on the hand press .
the socket fitting is marked purple .
insert the fitting as far as it will go , so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting .
tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the socket fitting . tighten the screw about a 1 /4 turn past finger-tight .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the socket fitting into the upper fitting holder on the hand press. The socket fitting is marked purple. Insert the fitting as far as it will go, so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting. Tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the socket fitting. Tighten the screw about a 1/4 turn past finger-tight.

Lines.Text: slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings .
the fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum .
if there is a gap in the fittings , adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings. The fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum. If there is a gap in the fittings, adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch.

Lines.Text: mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap .
align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the cap .
if the fabric is not laying flat , have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap .

Steps.Text_raw: Mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap. Align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the cap. If the fabric is not laying flat, have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap.

Lines.Text: with the fabric aligned , pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion .
setting a plastic snap requires little force . you will need to pull hard enough to get the press to its maximum range , but not beyond that .

Steps.Text_raw: With the fabric aligned, pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion. Setting a plastic snap requires little force. You will need to pull hard enough to get the press to its maximum range, but not beyond that.

Lines.Text: release the handle of the hand press , and remove the fabric .

inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric . when you inspect the socket side you should see that the nose of the cap has been pressed into a ring ; this is what holds the snap parts together .
if the snap is not set all the way , reinsert the snap into the hand press , aligning it as it was before , and repeat guide of this guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Release the handle of the hand press, and remove the fabric. Inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric. When you inspect the socket side you should see that the nose of the cap has been pressed into a ring; this is what holds the snap parts together. If the snap is not set all the way, reinsert the snap into the hand press, aligning it as it was before, and repeat [guide|16022|step 18|stepid=50185] of this guide.

Subject: Plastic Snap

Title: Installing a Metal Snap Using a Hand Press

Lines.Text: get a new stud .
get a new post .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a new stud. Get a new post.

Lines.Text: measure the diameter of the stud and post to make sure they are the correct size . ours are 1 /2.
if you're unsure of the correct size , measure a snap on the piece that you are repairing for reference .

Steps.Text_raw: Measure the diameter of the stud and post to make sure they are the correct size. Ours are 1/2". If you're unsure of the correct size, measure a snap on the piece that you are repairing for reference.

Lines.Text: insert the stud into the stud fitting for the hand press . the ridged part should set into the groove on the fitting . when correctly seated , the snap lays flat in the fitting .
the stud fitting is marked green .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the stud into the stud fitting for the hand press. The ridged part should set into the groove on the fitting. When correctly seated, the snap lays flat in the fitting. The stud fitting is marked green.

Lines.Text: insert the post into the post fitting for the hand press . the flat part of the post should sit inside the fitting with the shaft pointed out .
the post fitting is marked blue .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the post into the post fitting for the hand press. The flat part of the post should sit inside the fitting with the shaft pointed out. The post fitting is marked blue.

Lines.Text: insert the post fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press .
the post fitting is marked blue .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the post fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press. The post fitting is marked blue.

Lines.Text: insert the stud fitting into the upper fitting holder on the hand press .
the stud fitting is marked green .
insert the fitting as far as it will go , so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting .
tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the stud fitting . tighten the screw about a 1 /4 turn past finger-tight .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the stud fitting into the upper fitting holder on the hand press. The stud fitting is marked green. Insert the fitting as far as it will go, so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting. Tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the stud fitting. Tighten the screw about a 1/4 turn past finger-tight.

Lines.Text: slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings .
the fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum .
if there is a gap in the fittings , adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings. The fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum. If there is a gap in the fittings, adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch.

Lines.Text: mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap .
align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the post .
if the fabric is not laying flat , have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap .

Steps.Text_raw: Mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap. Align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the post. If the fabric is not laying flat, have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap.

Lines.Text: with the fabric aligned , pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion .
apply pressure until you feel the snap give .
setting a metal snap requires force . you will need to pull hard .

Steps.Text_raw: With the fabric aligned, pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion. Apply pressure until you feel the snap give. Setting a metal snap requires force. You will need to pull hard.

Lines.Text: release the handle of the hand press , and remove the fabric .
inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric .
if the snap is not set all the way , reinsert the snap into the hand press , aligning it as it was before , and repeat guide of this guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Release the handle of the hand press, and remove the fabric. Inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric. If the snap is not set all the way, reinsert the snap into the hand press, aligning it as it was before, and repeat [guide|16020|step 9|stepid=50155] of this guide.

Lines.Text: get a new cap .
get a new socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a new cap. Get a new socket.

Lines.Text: measure the diameter of the components to ensure that they are the correct size . these are 1 /2 in diameter .
if you are unsure of the correct size , measure a snap on the piece that you are repairing for reference .

Steps.Text_raw: Measure the diameter of the components to ensure that they are the correct size. These are 1/2" in diameter. If you are unsure of the correct size, measure a snap on the piece that you are repairing for reference.

Lines.Text: insert the cap , shaft facing out , into the cap fitting for the hand press . when correctly seated , the cap should not extend beyond the fitting .
the cap fitting is marked orange .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the cap, shaft facing out, into the cap fitting for the hand press. When correctly seated, the cap should not extend beyond the fitting. The cap fitting is marked orange.

Lines.Text: insert the socket into the socket fitting for the hand press . place the widest part of the socket facing the fitting . when correctly seated , the socket will snap on to the fitting and sit without being held .
the socket fitting is marked in purple .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the socket into the socket fitting for the hand press. Place the widest part of the socket facing the fitting. When correctly seated, the socket will snap on to the fitting and sit without being held. The socket fitting is marked in purple.

Lines.Text: insert the cap fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press .
the cap fitting is marked in orange .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the cap fitting onto the fitting base of the hand press. The cap fitting is marked in orange.

Lines.Text: insert the socket fitting into the upper fitting holder on the hand press .
the socket fitting is marked in purple .
insert the fitting as far as it will go , so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting .
tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the stud fitting . tighten the screw about a 1 /4 turn past finger-tight .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the socket fitting into the upper fitting holder on the hand press. The socket fitting is marked in purple. Insert the fitting as far as it will go, so that the only visible part is the wider encasement portion of the fitting. Tighten the screw on the side of the upper fitting holder to secure the stud fitting. Tighten the screw about a 1/4 turn past finger-tight.

Lines.Text: slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings .
the fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum .
if there is a gap in the fittings , adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch .
be careful to not let the handle flip back and hit you in the face .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly pull the handle on the hand press to test the range of the fittings. The fittings should just touch when the handle is pulled to its maximum. If there is a gap in the fittings, adjust the height of the fitting base on the hand press by turning it until the fittings touch. Be careful to not let the handle flip back and hit you in the face.

Lines.Text: mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap .
align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the post .
if the fabric is not laying flat , have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap .
the cap is on the bottom of the press . be sure that you place your fabric face down , so that the cap is on the correct side .

Steps.Text_raw: Mark the fabric where you will be inserting the snap. Align the fabric in the hand press so that the mark rests directly above the shaft of the post. If the fabric is not laying flat, have a friend pull the fabric taut to help keep it flat as you insert the snap. The cap is on the bottom of the press. Be sure that you place your fabric face down, so that the cap is on the correct side.

Lines.Text: with the fabric aligned , pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion .
apply pressure until you feel the snap give .
setting a metal snap requires force . you will need to pull hard .

Steps.Text_raw: With the fabric aligned, pull the handle of the hand press down in one continuous motion. Apply pressure until you feel the snap give. Setting a metal snap requires force. You will need to pull hard.

Lines.Text: release the handle of the hand press , and remove the fabric .
inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric .
if the snap is not set all the way , reinsert the snap into the hand press , aligning it as it was before , and repeat guide of this guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Release the handle of the hand press, and remove the fabric. Inspect both sides of your snap to make sure that it is laying flat and tight up against the fabric. If the snap is not set all the way, reinsert the snap into the hand press, aligning it as it was before, and repeat [guide|16020|step 19|stepid=50165] of this guide.

Subject: Metal Snap

Title: Replace the Slider on a Plastic Tooth Zipper

Lines.Text: locate the top of the zipper on the side with the slider .
use end nippers to cut the stop off of the zipper .
be careful to only cut the plastic , not the fabric .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the top of the zipper on the side with the slider. Use end nippers to cut the stop off of the zipper. Be careful to only cut the plastic, not the fabric.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to remove any remaining pieces of the stop from the garment .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to remove any remaining pieces of the stop from the garment.

Lines.Text: slide the slider off of the garment .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the slider off of the garment.

Lines.Text: insert the new slider onto the zipper .
you may need to tug a little to get the slider over the webbing from the old stop .
make sure the zipper slider is oriented right-side up when you slide it back onto the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the new slider onto the zipper. You may need to tug a little to get the slider over the webbing from the old stop. Make sure the zipper slider is oriented right-side up when you slide it back onto the zipper.

Lines.Text: grab a replacement stop .
position the new stop over the webbing in the same place where the old stop was located .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab a replacement stop. Position the new stop over the webbing in the same place where the old stop was located.

Lines.Text: use pliers to crimp the stop into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Use pliers to crimp the stop into place.

Subject: Plastic Zipper Slider

Lines.Text: lay your piece of hook-and-loop tape on the fabric where you would like it to live .
sewing glossarysection_pinspin the hook-and-loop tape into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay your piece of hook-and-loop tape on the fabric where you would like it to live. [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Pins|Pin]] the hook-and-loop tape into place.

Lines.Text: position your fabric under the sewing glossarysection_presser_footpresser foot of your sewing machine in the upper right hand corner of the hook-and-loop tape . drop the presser foot .
use the sewing glossarysection_balance_wheelbalance wheel to sink the needle .

the balance wheel should only be turned in the direction that advances the sewing machine . usually , this means turning the wheel towards you . turning the wheel in the opposite direction can ruin the tension on the sewing machine , causing it to jam . see your sewing machine manual for instructions specific to your machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Position your fabric under the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Presser_Foot|presser foot]] of your sewing machine in the upper right hand corner of the hook-and-loop tape. Drop the presser foot. Use the [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Balance_Wheel|balance wheel]] to sink the needle. The balance wheel should only be turned in the direction that advances the sewing machine. Usually, this means turning the wheel towards you. Turning the wheel in the opposite direction can ruin the tension on the sewing machine, causing it to jam. See your sewing machine manual for instructions specific to your machine.

Lines.Text: sew along the edge of the hook-and-loop tape , stopping just at the end .
pull the pin out .
when you pull the pin out , be sure the needle is already down . if not , use the balance wheel to sink the needle into the fabric .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew along the edge of the hook-and-loop tape, stopping just at the end. Pull the pin out. When you pull the pin out, be sure the needle is already down. If not, use the balance wheel to sink the needle into the fabric.

Lines.Text: lift the presser foot , leaving the needle sunk .
rotate the fabric 90 º counterclockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the presser foot, leaving the needle sunk. Rotate the fabric 90º counterclockwise.

Lines.Text: lower the presser foot and sew the second side of the hook-and-loop tape .
continue sewing the hook-and-loop tape . when you come to the end of a side , sink the needle into the fabric and lift the presser foot . then turn the fabric at each of the remaining corners .

Steps.Text_raw: Lower the presser foot and sew the second side of the hook-and-loop tape. Continue sewing the hook-and-loop tape. When you come to the end of a side, sink the needle into the fabric and lift the presser foot. Then turn the fabric at each of the remaining corners.

Lines.Text: on the last side of the hook-and-loop tape , sewing glossarysection_backstitchbackstitch over the last few stitches .

Steps.Text_raw: On the last side of the hook-and-loop tape, [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Backstitch|backstitch]] over the last few stitches.

Lines.Text: clip the threads , freeing the fabric from the sewing machine .
clip the extra thread off .
repeat this guide for the other side of the hook-and-loop tape .

Steps.Text_raw: Clip the threads, freeing the fabric from the sewing machine. Clip the extra thread off. Repeat this guide for the other side of the hook-and-loop tape.

Title: Replacing the Slider on a Coil Zipper

Lines.Text: locate the top of the zipper on the side with the slider .
peel back any fabric that is covering the zipper stop .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the top of the zipper on the side with the slider. Peel back any fabric that is covering the zipper stop.

Lines.Text: use end nippers to cut the stop .
be sure to only cut the plastic or metal stop . you do not want to damage the webbing behind the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Use end nippers to cut the stop. Be sure to only cut the plastic or metal stop. You do not want to damage the webbing behind the zipper.

Lines.Text: carefully remove any remaining pieces of the stop using tweezers .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove any remaining pieces of the stop using tweezers.

Lines.Text: slide the damaged zipper slider up and off of the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the damaged zipper slider up and off of the zipper.

Lines.Text: slide the replacement slider onto the zipper .
you may need to tug a little to get it past where the old stop was .
make sure that your zipper slider is facing the correct way ( right-side up ) when you place it onto the zipper .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the replacement slider onto the zipper. You may need to tug a little to get it past where the old stop was. Make sure that your zipper slider is facing the correct way (right-side up) when you place it onto the zipper.

Lines.Text: grab a new zipper stop .
insert the teeth into the webbing in the same place where the old stop was located .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab a new zipper stop. Insert the teeth into the webbing in the same place where the old stop was located.

Lines.Text: use pliers to bend the metal top of the zipper stop around the edge of the webbing , poking the single tooth on the stop through the backside of the webbing .
crimp the stop into place .

Steps.Text_raw: Use pliers to bend the metal top of the zipper stop around the edge of the webbing, poking the single tooth on the stop through the backside of the webbing. Crimp the stop into place.

Subject: Coil Zipper Slider

Title: How to Repair a Torn Seam in your Patagonia Clothing

Lines.Text: examine the damaged sewing glossarysection_seamseam in your garment , checking for tears and removing any loose threads .

Steps.Text_raw: Examine the damaged [[Sewing Glossary#Section_Seam|seam]] in your garment, checking for tears and removing any loose threads.

Lines.Text: flatten out the garment around the torn seam , and align the fabric where the seam used to be .
pin the two layers together . be sure to catch only the two layers of fabric you wish to sew back together .

Steps.Text_raw: Flatten out the garment around the torn seam, and align the fabric where the seam used to be. Pin the two layers together. Be sure to catch only the two layers of fabric you wish to sew back together.

Lines.Text: open the garment as much as possible , laying the seam flat .
check your alignment and make sure the two edges of your fabric line up .
put the garment in the machine , starting a few inches before the torn seam to overlap with the stitches .
drop the presser foot . align the first line of stitches with the needle .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the garment as much as possible, laying the seam flat. Check your alignment and make sure the two edges of your fabric line up. Put the garment in the machine, starting a few inches before the torn seam to overlap with the stitches. Drop the presser foot. Align the first line of stitches with the needle.

Lines.Text: use the balance wheel to sink the needle into the fabric .
only turn the balance wheel in the direction that advances the machine . turning the wheel the opposite direction can cause tangling or ruin the tension on the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the balance wheel to sink the needle into the fabric. Only turn the balance wheel in the direction that advances the machine. Turning the wheel the opposite direction can cause tangling or ruin the tension on the machine.

Lines.Text: sew along the first line of stitches , removing the pins before you get to them .
if you run over the pins , you risk breaking your needle .

Steps.Text_raw: Sew along the first line of stitches, removing the pins before you get to them. If you run over the pins, you risk breaking your needle.

Lines.Text: when you come to the end of the row of stitches , engage the backstitch function of your machine . backstitching prevents the seam from unraveling .
backstitch functions vary widely between machines and can come in the form of buttons , levers , and knobs . see your sewing machine manual for instructions on your backstitch function .
depress the pedal slowly . sew two or three stitches backwards . release the pedal and disengage the backstitch function .

Steps.Text_raw: When you come to the end of the row of stitches, engage the backstitch function of your machine. Backstitching prevents the seam from unraveling. Backstitch functions vary widely between machines and can come in the form of buttons, levers, and knobs. See your sewing machine manual for instructions on your backstitch function. Depress the pedal slowly. Sew two or three stitches backwards. Release the pedal and disengage the backstitch function.

Lines.Text: after you've completely sewn over the torn seam , clip the threads and free the garment from the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: After you've completely sewn over the torn seam, clip the threads and free the garment from the machine.

Lines.Text: some clothes have two rows of stitching , if your garment does , reposition it in the sewing machine . drop the needle into the second line of stitches at about where you began sewing your previous seam .
repeat steps 3-7 of this guide to resew the second line of stitches .
you do not need to pin this seam , because the first seam will hold the garment in place .
if your garment only has a single line of stitches , skip this step and proceed to the next step .

Steps.Text_raw: Some clothes have two rows of stitching, If your garment does, reposition it in the sewing machine. Drop the needle into the second line of stitches at about where you began sewing your previous seam. Repeat steps 3-7 of this guide to resew the second line of stitches. You do not need to pin this seam, because the first seam will hold the garment in place. If your garment only has a single line of stitches, skip this step and proceed to the next step.

Lines.Text: check that your stitches are straight and secure .
admire your work .

Steps.Text_raw: Check that your stitches are straight and secure. Admire your work.

Title: How to Iron a Waterproof Jacket

Lines.Text: unzip your clean jacket and slide one half over your ironing board .
you only want to iron through one layer of the jacket . ironing through two layers can create wrinkles in one side .
flatten your jacket with your hands .

Steps.Text_raw: Unzip your clean jacket and slide one half over your ironing board. You only want to iron through one layer of the jacket. Ironing through two layers can create wrinkles in one side. Flatten your jacket with your hands.

Lines.Text: set your iron to its lowest setting .
ensure that the steam function of your iron is off .
steam can melt your jacket . if you can't turn off the steam function on your iron , be sure to drain the water chamber of your iron .

Steps.Text_raw: Set your iron to its lowest setting. Ensure that the steam function of your iron is off. Steam can melt your jacket. If you can't turn off the steam function on your iron,  be sure to drain the water chamber of your iron.

Lines.Text: lay a towel over the area of your jacket that you'll be ironing .
smooth the towel out with your hands .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay a towel over the area of your jacket that you'll be ironing. Smooth the towel out with your hands.

Lines.Text: starting near the center , iron the jacket in one smooth stroke running parallel to the zipper .
only iron in one direction . each stroke should go in the same direction . change directions only when you move to a new section of the jacket .
do not press down with the iron . allow the heat and weight of the iron to do the work .
always keep the iron moving . stopping in one place can result in burnt fabric .

Steps.Text_raw: Starting near the center, iron the jacket in one smooth stroke running parallel to the zipper. Only iron in one direction. Each stroke should go in the same direction. Change directions only when you move to a new section of the jacket. Do not press down with the iron. Allow the heat and weight of the iron to do the work. Always keep the iron moving. Stopping in one place can result in burnt fabric.

Lines.Text: remove the towel from your jacket .
inspect your work .
if it looks as though the iron did nothing , you can increase the heat of your iron by one setting and try ironing again .
if your work looks good , position another section of the jacket flat on the ironing board , re-cover it with the towel and repeat the process until your whole jacket is wrinkle-free .
don't forget to turn off the iron when you finish .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the towel from your jacket. Inspect your work. If it looks as though the iron did nothing, you can increase the heat of your iron by one setting and try ironing again. If your work looks good, position another section of the jacket flat on the ironing board, re-cover it with the towel and repeat the process until your whole jacket is wrinkle-free. Don't forget to turn off the iron when you finish.

Lines.Text: before disassembling your gear , be sure it is powered off .
to remove each strap , locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the gear .
press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the gear until it is completely off .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling your Gear, be sure it is powered off. To remove each strap, locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the Gear. Press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the Gear until it is completely off.

Lines.Text: remove the four 4.0 mm screws on the back of the gear using a t5 torx screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 4.0 mm screws on the back of the Gear using a T5 Torx Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: firmly holding the gear , insert the flat side of the spudger at an angle to pry the back casing off of the device . move the spudger along the sides of the gear to completely detach the back and front components .
pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly holding the Gear, insert the flat side of the spudger at an angle to pry the back casing off of the device. Move the spudger along the sides of the Gear to completely detach the back and front components. Pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side.

Lines.Text: use the pointed side of the spudger to remove the small , orange battery cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the pointed side of the spudger to remove the small, orange battery cable.

Lines.Text: remove the battery by pulling the white tab on the battery marked pull .
make sure the orange battery cable is fully disconnected to avoid ripping it off and tearing it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery by pulling the white tab on the battery marked "PULL." Make sure the orange battery cable is fully disconnected to avoid ripping it off and tearing it.

to remove each strap , locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the gear .
press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the gear until it is completely off .

pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly holding the Gear, insert the flat side of the spudger at an angle to pry the back casing off of the device. Move the spudger along the sides of the Gear to completely detach the back and front components. Pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side.

Lines.Text: locate the rectangular metal connector that attaches the camera to the gear .
use tweezers to gently lift and detach the metal plate of the connector .

when reassembling the gear , reattach the camera connector by carefully aligning the metal plate and its pins to its original placement . make sure it snaps in place to avoid improper connections and possible damage .

When reassembling the Gear, reattach the camera connector by carefully aligning the metal plate and its pins to its original placement. Make sure it snaps in place to avoid improper connections and possible damage.

to remove each strap , locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the gear .
press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the gear until it is completely off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 4.0 mm screws on the back of the Gear using a T5 Torx Screwdriver.

pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly holding the Gear, insert the flat side of the spudger at an angle to pry the back casing off of the device. Move the spudger along the sides of the Gear to completely detach the back and front components. Pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side.

Lines.Text: locate the rectangular metal connector that attaches the camera to the gear .
use tweezers to gently lift and detach the metal plate of the connector .

when reassembling the gear , reattach the camera connector by carefully aligning the metal plate and its pins to its original placement . make sure it snaps in place to avoid improper connections and possible damage .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the rectangular metal connector that attaches the camera to the Gear. Use tweezers to gently lift and detach the metal plate of the connector. When reassembling the Gear, reattach the camera connector by carefully aligning the metal plate and its pins to its original placement. Make sure it snaps in place to avoid improper connections and possible damage.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to carefully lift the camera from its slot out of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to carefully lift the camera from its slot out of the case.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to grab and then gently lift up the metal plate of the safety belt .
when removing the metal plate , be sure to remove them carefully as to not rip the orange tape that is attached to them .
during reassembly , be sure to line up the pins of the metal plate in order to reattach correctly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to grab and then gently lift up the metal plate of the safety belt. When removing the metal plate, be sure to remove them carefully as to not rip the orange tape that is attached to them. to remove each strap , locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the gear .
press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the gear until it is completely off .

make sure the orange battery cable is fully disconnected to avoid ripping it off and tearing it .

be careful to not pull too quickly and rip the orange connector cable , which is attached to the case with adhesive .

gently pull upwards to detach it from the case and from the adhesive .

to remove each strap , locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the gear .
press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the gear until it is completely off .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling your Gear, be sure it is powered off. To remove each strap, locate the metal latches on both sides of the back of the Gear. Press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the Gear until it is completely off.

Lines.Text: remove the four 4.0 mm screws on the back of the gear using a t5 torx screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 4.0 mm screws on the back of the Gear using a T5 Torx Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: firmly holding the gear , insert the flat side of the spudger at an angle to pry the back casing off of the device . move the spudger along the sides of the gear to completely detach the back and front components .
pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly holding the Gear, insert the flat side of the spudger at an angle to pry the back casing off of the device. Move the spudger along the sides of the Gear to completely detach the back and front components. Pry the device open from the other side also if it does not fully disassemble from one side.

Lines.Text: locate the rectangular metal connector that attaches the camera to the gear .
use tweezers to gently lift and detach the metal plate of the connector .

when reassembling the gear , reattach the camera connector by carefully aligning the metal plate and its pins to its original placement . make sure it snaps in place to avoid improper connections and possible damage .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the rectangular metal connector that attaches the camera to the Gear. Use tweezers to gently lift and detach the metal plate of the connector. When reassembling the Gear, reattach the camera connector by carefully aligning the metal plate and its pins to its original placement. Make sure it snaps in place to avoid improper connections and possible damage.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to carefully lift the camera from its slot out of the case .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to carefully lift the camera from its slot out of the case.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to grab and then gently lift up the metal plate of the safety belt .
when removing the metal plate , be sure to remove them carefully as to not rip the orange tape that is attached to them .
during reassembly , be sure to line up the pins of the metal plate in order to reattach correctly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to grab and then gently lift up the metal plate of the safety belt. When removing the metal plate, be sure to remove them carefully as to not rip the orange tape that is attached to them. During reassembly, be sure to line up the pins of the metal plate in order to reattach correctly.

Lines.Text: once the safety belt is removed , use tweezers to take the motherboard out of the gear 2.

Steps.Text_raw: Once the safety belt is removed, use tweezers to take the motherboard out of the Gear 2.

Lines.Text: insert the spudger into the small opening underneath the black home button assembly and pry it off the casing .
lift up to detach the black assembly .
be sure not to rip the orange tape that keeps the home button assembly attached to the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the spudger into the small opening underneath the black home button assembly and pry it off the casing. Lift up to detach the black assembly. Be sure not to rip the orange tape that keeps the home button assembly attached to the device.

Lines.Text: use tweezers to grab the orange connector that is attached to side the home button assembly and lift to remove it from its adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Use tweezers to grab the orange connector that is attached to side the home button assembly and lift to remove it from its adhesive.

Lines.Text: using two spudgers , place the pointed tips at each end of the u-shaped snap ring located under where the home button assembly was .
remove the snap ring by pushing down with both pointed objects on each side of the ring simultaneously , it should pop off .
be careful not to lose the snap ring because it can be lost easily .

to replace the snap ring , rest it above the home button peg using tweezers so the open side rests on the peg . then use the flat end of the spudger and push firmly down on the snap ring to snap it back onto the peg as shown in the last picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Using two spudgers, place the pointed tips at each end of the U-shaped snap ring located under where the home button assembly was. Remove the snap ring by pushing down with both pointed objects on each side of the ring simultaneously, it should pop off. Be careful not to lose the snap ring because it can be lost easily. To replace the snap ring, rest it above the home button peg using tweezers so the open side rests on the peg. Then use the flat end of the spudger and push firmly down on the snap ring to snap it back onto the peg as shown in the last picture.

Lines.Text: use either the tweezers or the spudger to push the button peg out through the hole .

Steps.Text_raw: Use either the tweezers or the spudger to push the button peg out through the hole.

press down on the metal latch while pulling the strap away from the gear until it is completely off .

Lines.Text: place your thumbs on the ends of the screen .
push the watch outward while pulling the band away from the watch .

Steps.Text_raw: Place your thumbs on the ends of the screen. Push the watch outward while pulling the band away from the watch.

Lines.Text: heating the device with a hair dryer may warp the screen or damage the device . it it preferable to use an iopener for this step .
for step-by-step instructions on using an iopener , see the guide11677.
use a hair dryer , heat gun , or an iopener to heat the gear fit for 1-2 minutes until it is hot to the touch .

Lines.Text: the screen is connected to the device by a ribbon cable on the left side with the power button facing you . do not try to completely separate the screen from the device yet , and be careful .
gently pry the screen loose using a plastic opening tool .
if the screen doesn't easily come loose , more heating may be required

this will be harder than removing the screen . moderate force may be required .

Lines.Text: gently peel the screen assembly up and away from the device using tweezers .

Lines.Text: three ribbon cables hold the motherboard to the rest of the assembly .
the battery cable in the front .
when reassembling the device , make sure the battery cable is securely connected . moderate force may be required to push it in all the way .
and two on the side .
using a pair of tweezers , carefully pull each connector away to disconnect it from the rest of the assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Three ribbon cables hold the motherboard to the rest of the assembly. The battery cable in the front. When reassembling the device, make sure the battery cable is securely connected.  Moderate force may be required to push it in all the way. And two on the side. Using a pair of tweezers, carefully pull each connector away to disconnect it from the rest of the assembly.

Lines.Text: the motherboard is a segmented three piece construction .
use tweezers to first lift up , with a moderate amount of force , and free each ends of the motherboard from the assembly .
be sure to use esd safe tweezers to prevent static discharge from zapping your device .

Steps.Text_raw: The motherboard is a segmented three piece construction. Use tweezers to first lift up, with a moderate amount of force, and free each ends of the motherboard from the assembly. Be sure to use ESD safe tweezers to prevent static discharge from zapping your device.

Lines.Text: the motherboard should now be removable from the assembly .
use tweezers to lightly pry , lift , and remove the board by its middle section .
if the motherboard is stuck it may be caught on the assembly . wiggle it around to free it . you may also need to pull the edges of the assembly away from the motherboard to create space .

Steps.Text_raw: The motherboard should now be removable from the assembly. Use tweezers to lightly pry, lift, and remove the board by its middle section. If the motherboard is stuck it may be caught on the assembly.  Wiggle it around to free it.  You may also need to pull the edges of the assembly away from the motherboard to create space.

Lines.Text: place your thumbs on the ends of the screen .
push the watch outward while pulling the band away from the watch .
